}</script>

}</script>
<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Pharrell_Williams skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Pharrell Williams</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-pc1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-pc1 (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-pc1</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_musical_artist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox musical artist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox musical artist</a>
</p><p><b>Pharrell Williams</b> (born April 5, 1973), also known as <b>Pharrell</b>, is an American <a href="/wiki/Singer-songwriter" title="Singer-songwriter">singer-songwriter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapper" title="Rapper" class="mw-redirect">rapper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Record_producer" title="Record producer">record producer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fashion_designer" title="Fashion designer" class="mw-redirect">fashion designer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Drummer" title="Drummer">drummer</a>. Williams and <a href="/wiki/Chad_Hugo" title="Chad Hugo">Chad Hugo</a> make up the record production duo <a href="/wiki/The_Neptunes" title="The Neptunes">The Neptunes</a>, producing <a href="/wiki/Soul_music" title="Soul music">soul</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hip_hop_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hip hop music (page does not exist)">hip hop</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Contemporary_R%26B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Contemporary R&amp;B (page does not exist)">R&amp;B</a> music. He is also the lead vocalist and drummer of rock, funk, and hip hop band <a href="/wiki/N.E.R.D" title="N.E.R.D">N.E.R.D</a>, which he formed with Hugo and childhood friend <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shay_Haley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shay Haley (page does not exist)">Shay Haley</a>. He released his first single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Frontin%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frontin' (page does not exist)">Frontin'</a>" in 2003 and followed up with his debut solo album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=In_My_Mind_(Pharrell_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="In My Mind (Pharrell album) (page does not exist)">In My Mind</a></i> in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> He will release his second album in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-second_album_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-second_album-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>As part of The Neptunes, Williams has produced numerous hit singles for <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Neptunes_production_discography&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Neptunes production discography (page does not exist)">various musicians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Williams has earned seven <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a> including two with The Neptunes. He currently owns a media venture that encompasses entertainment, music, fashion, and art called <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_am_OTHER&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I am OTHER (page does not exist)">i am OTHER</a>. He is also the co-founder of the clothing brands <a href="/w/index.php?title=Billionaire_Boys_Club_(clothing_retailer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billionaire Boys Club (clothing retailer) (page does not exist)">Billionaire Boys Club</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Billionaire_Boys_Club_(clothing_retailer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billionaire Boys Club (clothing retailer) (page does not exist)">Ice Cream</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early life</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-5"><a href="#2005.E2.80.932009:_First_album_and_collaborations"><span class="tocnumber">2.3</span> <span class="toctext">2005–2009: First album and collaborations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#2010.E2.80.932012:_Despicable_Me.2C_Nothing_and_other_collaborations"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">2010–2012: <i>Despicable Me</i>, <i>Nothing</i> and other collaborations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-7"><a href="#2013.E2.80.93Present:_Second_studio_album_and_collaborations"><span class="tocnumber">2.5</span> <span class="toctext">2013–Present: Second studio album and collaborations</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Musical_style"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Musical style</span></a></li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-11"><a href="#Discography"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Discography</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-12"><a href="#Awards_and_nominations"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Awards and nominations</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-13"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Pharrell Williams was born on April 5, 1973, in <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Beach,_Virginia" title="Virginia Beach, Virginia">Virginia Beach, Virginia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Allmusic_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Allmusic-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian-5">[5]</a></sup> the oldest of three sons of Carolyn, a teacher, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sic (page does not exist)">Template:Sic</a> Williams, a handyman.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>  He met <a href="/wiki/Chad_Hugo" title="Chad Hugo">Chad Hugo</a> in a seventh-grade summer band camp where Williams played the <a href="/wiki/Keyboard_instrument" title="Keyboard instrument">keyboards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Drum_kit" title="Drum kit">drums</a> and Hugo played <a href="/wiki/Tenor_saxophone" title="Tenor saxophone">tenor saxophone</a>. They were also both members of a <a href="/wiki/Marching_band" title="Marching band">marching band</a>; Williams played the <a href="/wiki/Snare_drum" title="Snare drum">snare drum</a> while Hugo was student <a href="/wiki/Conducting" title="Conducting">conductor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Age_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Age-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Williams attended <a href="/w/index.php?title=Princess_Anne_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Princess Anne High School (page does not exist)">Princess Anne High School</a> where he played in the school band; there he got the name Skateboard P.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> Hugo attended Kempsville High School.
</p><p>In the 1990s, Hugo and Williams formed a four-piece "R&amp;B type" group, <i>The Neptunes</i>, with friends <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shay_Haley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shay Haley (page does not exist)">Shay Haley</a> and Mike Etheridge. They later entered a high school talent show where they were discovered by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Teddy_Riley_(producer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Teddy Riley (producer) (page does not exist)">Teddy Riley</a>, whose studio was next to Princess Anne High School.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> After graduating from high school, the group signed with Riley.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1992.E2.80.931997:_Career_beginnings">1992–1997: Career beginnings</span></h3>
<p>Through working with Riley, Williams went on to write a verse and help produce for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wreckx-N-Effect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wreckx-N-Effect (page does not exist)">Wreckx-N-Effect</a>'s 1992 hit "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rump_Shaker_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rump Shaker (song) (page does not exist)">Rump Shaker</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> That same year, he also performed a small rap solo on <a href="/wiki/SWV" title="SWV">SWV</a>'s second hit, "Right Here (UK Remix)". In 1994, Hugo and Williams had established themselves as a production duo under their old name "The Neptunes", and produced "Tonight's The Night" from <a href="/wiki/Blackstreet" title="Blackstreet">Blackstreet</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blackstreet_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blackstreet (album) (page does not exist)">self-titled album</a>. Over the next three years they continued to produce occasionally, and some of the results had little resemblance to the Neptunes sound later. However, some like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mase&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mase (page does not exist)">Mase</a>'s 1997 song "Lookin' at Me" from his album <i><a href="/wiki/Harlem_World" title="Harlem World">Harlem World</a></i>, and the most definite beginning of the distinctive "Neptunes sound", came with <a href="/wiki/N.O.R.E" title="N.O.R.E" class="mw-redirect">N.O.R.E</a>'s "Superthug" in 1998, reaching number 36 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a>, and gaining them widespread attention for the first time. In 1999, a mutual friend introduced Pharrell to <a href="/wiki/Kelis" title="Kelis">Kelis</a>, and their resulting collaboration produced her first album <i><a href="/wiki/Kaleidoscope_(Kelis_album)" title="Kaleidoscope (Kelis album)">Kaleidoscope</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1998.E2.80.932004:_The_Neptunes">1998–2004: The Neptunes</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PHARRELL_WILLIAMS_by_foto_di_matti.jpg" title="File:PHARRELL WILLIAMS by foto di matti.jpg">File:PHARRELL WILLIAMS by foto di matti.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pharrell Williams in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, March 2005</div></div></div>
<p>At this point The Neptunes were gaining a wide fanbase and audience.
In 2001, The Neptunes produced <a href="/wiki/Britney_Spears" title="Britney Spears">Britney Spears</a>' single, "<a href="/wiki/I%27m_a_Slave_4_U" title="I'm a Slave 4 U">I'm a Slave 4 U</a>" gaining their first worldwide number one.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The same year, N.E.R.D, consisting of Williams, Hugo and Haley, released their first album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=In_Search_Of..._(N.E.R.D_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="In Search Of... (N.E.R.D album) (page does not exist)">In Search of...</a></i>, in Europe, where the first Kelis album was better received. The album sounded very much like their previous production work; the group decided that they should make their work as N.E.R.D sound different, and re-recorded the album with the <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> band <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spymob&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spymob (page does not exist)">Spymob</a>. Williams and Hugo met rap duo <a href="/wiki/Clipse" title="Clipse">Clipse</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Beach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Beach (page does not exist)">Virginia Beach</a> in 1993, where they were signed to <a href="/wiki/Arista_Records" title="Arista Records">Arista Records</a> through Williams' <a href="/wiki/Star_Trak_Entertainment" title="Star Trak Entertainment">Star Trak Entertainment</a> imprint.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Yale_Daily_News_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Yale_Daily_News-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Then in 2002 their re-produced album was released worldwide, and The Neptunes reached number one in the U.S. with Nelly's single, "<a href="/wiki/Hot_in_Herre" title="Hot in Herre">Hot in Herre</a>". In August of the same year, The Neptunes were named "Producers of the Year" at both <a href="/wiki/The_Source_(magazine)" title="The Source (magazine)">The Source Awards</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Music_Award" title="Billboard Music Award">Billboard Music Awards</a>. Clipse released their commercial debut album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lord_Willin%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lord Willin' (page does not exist)">Lord Willin'</a></i> in August 2002. The album started at number one on the <i>Billboard</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Albums&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums (page does not exist)">Top R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums</a> chart and number four on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a>, fueled by its first two singles, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Grindin%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grindin' (page does not exist)">Grindin'</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=When_the_Last_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="When the Last Time (page does not exist)">When the Last Time</a>", which peaked at number 34 and number 19 respectively on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100.
</p><p>The Neptunes released a self-credited album called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Clones_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clones (album) (page does not exist)">The Neptunes Present... Clones</a></i> in 2003, with songs and remixes from various artists. This topped the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">U.S.</a> <i>Billboard</i> 200 Albums Chart. The Neptunes and Williams specifically were also kept in public eye largely due to ties with <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>, producing several hit singles for him and two tracks on his <i><a href="/wiki/The_Black_Album_(Jay-Z_album)" title="The Black Album (Jay-Z album)">The Black Album</a></i>. The track "Frontin'" was a big hit (the 34th biggest of 2003 according to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i>). A survey in August 2003 found the Neptunes produced almost 20 percent of songs played on British radio at the time, a survey in the US had them at 43 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-Age_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Age-7">[7]</a></sup> The same year, The Neptunes remixed the <a href="/wiki/Daft_Punk" title="Daft Punk">Daft Punk</a> song <i><a href="/wiki/Harder,_Better,_Faster,_Stronger" title="Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger">Harder, Better, Faster, Stronger</a></i> for the duo's poorly received remix album <i><a href="/wiki/Daft_Club" title="Daft Club">Daft Club</a></i>.  The track also had a brief rap section performed by Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-Fekadu_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fekadu-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>N.E.R.D's second <a href="/w/index.php?title=Funk_rock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Funk rock (page does not exist)">funk rock</a>-oriented album, <i><a href="/wiki/Fly_or_Die" title="Fly or Die">Fly or Die</a></i>, released in March 2004. Williams' rock credentials were further bolstered by his appearance at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2004_Grammy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2004 Grammy Awards (page does not exist)">2004 Grammy Awards</a>, performing <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a>' "<a href="/wiki/Please_Please_Me#.22I_Saw_Her_Standing_There.22" title="Please Please Me">I Saw Her Standing There</a>" on drums with <a href="/wiki/Sting_(musician)" title="Sting (musician)">Sting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dave_Matthews" title="Dave Matthews">Dave Matthews</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vince_Gill" title="Vince Gill">Vince Gill</a>. Williams received two Grammy Awards that night, one for <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Producer_of_the_Year,_Non-Classical" title="Grammy Award for Producer of the Year, Non-Classical">Producer of the Year, Non-Classical</a>, and another for <a href="/wiki/Best_Pop_Vocal_Album" title="Best Pop Vocal Album" class="mw-redirect">Best Pop Vocal Album</a> for his work on <a href="/wiki/Justin_Timberlake" title="Justin Timberlake">Justin Timberlake</a>'s hit album <i><a href="/wiki/Justified_(album)" title="Justified (album)">Justified</a></i>. They also gained their first UK number one, again with Nelly, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Flap_Your_Wings_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flap Your Wings (song) (page does not exist)">Flap Your Wings</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2005.E2.80.932009:_First_album_and_collaborations">2005–2009: First album and collaborations</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Astronaut_Leland_Melvin,_and_Pharrell_Williams_present_montage_to_Quincy_Jones.jpg" title="File:Astronaut Leland Melvin, and Pharrell Williams present montage to Quincy Jones.jpg">File:Astronaut Leland Melvin, and Pharrell Williams present montage to Quincy Jones.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Williams and American astronaut <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leland_D._Melvin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leland D. Melvin (page does not exist)">Leland D. Melvin</a> present a montage to record producer <a href="/wiki/Quincy_Jones" title="Quincy Jones">Quincy Jones</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>On September 9, 2005, Williams performed the opening single from his first solo album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=In_My_Mind_(Pharrell_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="In My Mind (Pharrell album) (page does not exist)">In My Mind</a></i>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Can_I_Have_It_Like_That&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Can I Have It Like That (page does not exist)">Can I Have It Like That</a>", featuring <a href="/wiki/Gwen_Stefani" title="Gwen Stefani">Gwen Stefani</a>. The single did poorly in the US, reaching only number 48. It fared better in the UK, reaching number three. Between then and the July 25, 2006 release of "In My Mind", he released "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Angel_(Pharrell_Williams_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Angel (Pharrell Williams song) (page does not exist)">Angel</a>" (in Europe only), and later "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Number_One_(Pharrell_Williams_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Number One (Pharrell Williams song) (page does not exist)">Number One</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>. Several songs leaked to the internet before the album release, most notably "Mamacita" featuring <a href="/wiki/Daddy_Yankee" title="Daddy Yankee">Daddy Yankee</a>, which was subsequently cut from the final version. "That Girl" featuring <a href="/wiki/Snoop_Dogg" title="Snoop Dogg">Snoop Dogg</a> was the final single.
</p><p>In 2006, Williams produced <a href="/wiki/Clipse" title="Clipse">Clipse</a>'s second album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hell_Hath_No_Fury&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hell Hath No Fury (page does not exist)">Hell Hath No Fury</a></i>. Most critics labeled the album Williams's best production in years, and put the duo back in the charts.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> A year later, Williams collaborated with <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a>, on the song "Hey You", which was available for download on the <a href="/wiki/MSN" title="MSN">MSN</a> website. 25 cents for each of the first one million downloads was donated to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alliance_for_Climate_Protection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alliance for Climate Protection (page does not exist)">Alliance for Climate Protection</a>, in support of Live Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Later that year, Williams performed songs at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Concert_for_Diana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Concert for Diana (page does not exist)">Concert for Diana</a> on July 1, 2007. On July 7, he performed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_Earth_concert,_Rio_de_Janeiro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live Earth concert, Rio de Janeiro (page does not exist)">Brazilian leg</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_Earth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live Earth (page does not exist)">Live Earth</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>.
</p><p>A remix album of Pharrell's solo debut, In My Mind, titled <i>Out of My Mind</i>, was recorded with his newly formed band "The Yessirs" featuring <a href="/wiki/Questlove" title="Questlove">Questlove</a> of <a href="/wiki/The_Roots" title="The Roots">The Roots</a> and was produced by Questlove and keyboardist James Poyser. However, Williams' record label Interscope Records did not think that the album would sell well and subsequently was shelved.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>  The album has built up a strong fanbase asking for its release. The tracks started appearing on&#160;?uestlove's MySpace, and with every 10,000 plays, a new song was made available. As of July 4, 2007, the full CD has leaked onto the internet along with two songs not featured on 'In My Mind';  a remix of "Mamacita" and "Creamsickle".  
</p><p>He also produced <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a>'s version of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamonds_Are_a_Girl%27s_Best_Friend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend (page does not exist)">Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend</a>". He then wrote and produced "Why Should I Be Sad" on <a href="/wiki/Britney_Spears" title="Britney Spears">Britney Spears</a>' fifth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Blackout_(Britney_Spears_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blackout (Britney Spears album) (page does not exist)">Blackout</a></i>. He also produced two songs from <a href="/wiki/The_Hives" title="The Hives">The Hives</a> album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Black_and_White_Album&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Black and White Album (page does not exist)">The Black and White Album</a></i>, titled "Well All Right!" and "T.H.E.H.I.V.E.S.".
</p><p>In April 2008, <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a> released her eleventh album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hard_Candy_(Madonna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hard Candy (Madonna album) (page does not exist)">Hard Candy</a></i>, which featured vocals from Williams and production from The Neptunes on several tracks. In June, an article in NME revealed that Williams was very interested in producing <a href="/wiki/The_Strokes" title="The Strokes">The Strokes</a>' fourth album.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> Later that year, Williams worked on a remix album for <a href="/wiki/Maroon_5" title="Maroon 5">Maroon 5</a>'s <i>Call &amp; Response</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Williams continued working with a variety of artists, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shakira&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shakira (page does not exist)">Shakira</a> on the songs '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Did_It_Again_(Shakira_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Did It Again (Shakira song) (page does not exist)">Did It Again</a>', 'Why Wait', 'Good Stuff' and 'Long Time' for her sixth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=She_Wolf_(Shakira_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="She Wolf (Shakira album) (page does not exist)">She Wolf</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> In September 2009, Williams was credited as a co-writer and producer of the song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fresh_Out_the_Oven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fresh Out the Oven (page does not exist)">Fresh Out the Oven</a>" for <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Lopez" title="Jennifer Lopez">Jennifer Lopez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> It was released as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buzz_single&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buzz single (page does not exist)">buzz single</a> from Lopez's seventh studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Love%3F_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love? (album) (page does not exist)">Love?</a></i> The following month, Williams made a guest appearance on <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">French</a> <a href="/wiki/Independent_music" title="Independent music">indie</a>/<a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic</a> rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uffie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uffie (page does not exist)">Uffie's</a> first album, which arrived in early 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Busy_P_Blog_10.2F03.2F2009_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Busy_P_Blog_10.2F03.2F2009-24">[24]</a></sup> In late 2009, Williams worked with the rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Game_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Game (rapper) (page does not exist)">Game</a> on his fourth studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_R.E.D._Album&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The R.E.D. Album (page does not exist)">The R.E.D. Album</a>.</i>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2010.E2.80.932012:_Despicable_Me.2C_Nothing_and_other_collaborations">2010–2012: <i>Despicable Me</i>, <i>Nothing</i> and other collaborations</span></h3>
<p>In July 2010, Williams composed the soundtrack to the movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Despicable_Me&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Despicable Me (page does not exist)">Despicable Me</a></i>, produced by <a href="/wiki/Hans_Zimmer" title="Hans Zimmer">Hans Zimmer</a> and recorded with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Studio_Symphony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hollywood Studio Symphony (page does not exist)">Hollywood Studio Symphony</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> In October 2010, Williams and his group <a href="/wiki/N.E.R.D" title="N.E.R.D">N.E.R.D</a> supported <a href="/wiki/Gorillaz" title="Gorillaz">Gorillaz</a> on their <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Escape_to_Plastic_Beach_World_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Escape to Plastic Beach World Tour (page does not exist)">Escape to Plastic Beach World Tour</a></i>. On the tour, <a href="/wiki/Damon_Albarn" title="Damon Albarn">Damon Albarn</a> recorded a song with Williams but this was not featured on Gorillaz's album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Fall_(Gorillaz_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Fall (Gorillaz album) (page does not exist)">The Fall</a></i>, but it may appear on a future album.<sup id="cite_ref-Fekadu_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fekadu-16">[16]</a></sup> The following month, N.E.R.D released their fourth studio album <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nothing_(N.E.R.D._album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nothing (N.E.R.D. album) (page does not exist)">Nothing</a> through Pharrell's label <a href="/w/index.php?title=Star_Trak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Star Trak (page does not exist)">Star Trak</a>. In late 2011, Williams worked on three tracks for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Posner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mike Posner (page does not exist)">Mike Posner</a>'s second album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sky_High_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sky High (album) (page does not exist)">Sky High</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, Williams collaborated with singer/composer Adam Lambert, co-writing two tracks for Lambert's album "Trespassing", which was released in May 2012, including the title track and "Kickin' In".
</p><p>In 2012, it was announced on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lupe_Fiasco&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lupe Fiasco (page does not exist)">Lupe Fiasco</a>'s website that he and Lupe will work on a collaborative album and work on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Waka_Flocka_Flame&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Waka Flocka Flame (page does not exist)">Waka Flocka Flame</a>'s album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Triple_F_Life:_Friends,_Fans_and_Family&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Triple F Life: Friends, Fans and Family (page does not exist)">Triple F Life: Friends, Fans and Family</a></i>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>He has also collaborated with Pittsburgh rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mac_Miller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mac Miller (page does not exist)">Mac Miller</a> on the "Pink Slime" EP. The first track, "Onaroll" was followed by "Glow". It was produced by Pharrell, with vocals from Mac Miller.
</p><p>Williams composed and produced the music for the 84th Academy Awards alongside composer <a href="/wiki/Hans_Zimmer" title="Hans Zimmer">Hans Zimmer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84th_academy_awards_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84th_academy_awards-27">[27]</a></sup> He is also collaborating with the singer-songwriter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Miley_Cyrus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Miley Cyrus (page does not exist)">Miley Cyrus</a> on her new album and composed the new intro music for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chelsea_Lately&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chelsea Lately (page does not exist)">Chelsea Lately</a></i> in 2012. He later contributed four tracks to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Game_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Game (rapper) (page does not exist)">The Game</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=California_Republic_(mixtape)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="California Republic (mixtape) (page does not exist)">California Republic</a></i> mixtape called "When My Niggas Come Home" and "It Must be Tough"; produced two tracks on <a href="/wiki/Usher_(entertainer)" title="Usher (entertainer)">Usher</a>'s 2012 seventh studio album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Looking_4_Myself&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Looking 4 Myself (page does not exist)">Looking 4 Myself</a>,</i> titled "Twisted" and "Hot Thing";<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> collaborated with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mika_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mika (singer) (page does not exist)">Mika</a> on his new track "Celebrate"; co-produced the tracks "Sweet Life" and "Golden Girl" from Frank Ocean's debut album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Channel_Orange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Channel Orange (page does not exist)">Channel Orange</a></i>; and is working with <a href="/wiki/Solange_Knowles" title="Solange Knowles">Solange Knowles</a> on her third studio album.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2013.E2.80.93Present:_Second_studio_album_and_collaborations">2013–Present: Second studio album and collaborations</span></h3>
<p>Pharrell featured on <a href="/wiki/Daft_Punk" title="Daft Punk">Daft Punk</a>'s fourth studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Random_Access_Memories&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Random Access Memories (page does not exist)">Random Access Memories</a></i> on songs "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Get_Lucky_(Daft_Punk_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Get Lucky (Daft Punk song) (page does not exist)">Get Lucky</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lose_Yourself_to_Dance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lose Yourself to Dance (page does not exist)">Lose Yourself to Dance</a>".  In addition, Williams contributed to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azealia_Banks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azealia Banks (page does not exist)">Azealia Banks</a>' debut studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Broke_with_Expensive_Taste&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Broke with Expensive Taste (page does not exist)">Broke with Expensive Taste</a></i>, featuring on the song "ATM Jam."<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>Williams penned three new original songs, included alongside composer Heitor Pereira's score, for the sequel <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Despicable_Me_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Despicable Me 2 (page does not exist)">Despicable Me 2</a></i>. These were "Just a Cloud Away", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Happy_(Pharrell_Williams_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Happy (Pharrell Williams song) (page does not exist)">Happy</a>", and "Scream" (featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cee_Lo_Green&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cee Lo Green (page does not exist)">Cee Lo Green</a>). His two original songs from the first film were also reprised on the soundtrack - "Despicable Me" and "Fun, Fun, Fun".<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>He also participated in the drummer sessions of the soundtrack of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Man_of_Steel_(soundtrack)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Man of Steel (soundtrack) (page does not exist)">Man of Steel</a> by Hans Zimmer.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2013, Pharrell appeared alongside <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robin_Thicke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robin Thicke (page does not exist)">Robin Thicke</a>'s hit single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Blurred_Lines_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blurred Lines (song) (page does not exist)">Blurred Lines</a>". The song has been a worldwide hit, has peaked at number one on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100, and has also reached number one in 13 more countries including the United Kingdom and Germany, making it Pharrell's third <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 number one single.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> On June 29, 2013, Pharrell became the 12th artist in the chart's history to simultaneously hold the number one and two positions with "Blurred Lines" and "Get Lucky", respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p>By July 2013 there had only been 137 singles in UK chart history to have sold 1 million copies in the UK; that month Pharrell scored two million-sellers with "Get Lucky" and "Blurred Lines".<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 2013, <a href="/wiki/Busta_Rhymes" title="Busta Rhymes">Busta Rhymes</a> talked about an unreleased "documentary album" by Pharrell where he talks about "inner-city strife and hardship".<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2013, Pharrell released the <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_24-hour_music_video&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First 24-hour music video (page does not exist)">first 24-hour music video</a> to his <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Despicable_Me_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Despicable Me 2 (page does not exist)">Despicable Me 2</a></i> collaboration song, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Happy_(Pharrell_Williams_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Happy (Pharrell Williams song) (page does not exist)">Happy</a>". Guest appearances included <a href="/wiki/Magic_Johnson" title="Magic Johnson">Magic Johnson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Carrell" title="Steve Carrell" class="mw-redirect">Steve Carrell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel" title="Jimmy Kimmel">Jimmy Kimmel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamie_Foxx" title="Jamie Foxx">Jamie Foxx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_Martin" title="Steve Martin">Steve Martin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Odd_Future&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Odd Future (page does not exist)">Odd Future</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miranda_Cosgrove" title="Miranda Cosgrove">Miranda Cosgrove</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Janelle_Mon%C3%A1e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Janelle Monáe (page does not exist)">Janelle Monáe</a>, and many others.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> It has received approximately 5.5 million views as of Christmas Day, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-melena_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-melena-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>It was announced in December 2013 that Williams had been nominated for seven Grammy Awards, including Producer of the Year.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> In the same month, a press release from <a href="/wiki/Columbia_Records" title="Columbia Records">Columbia Records</a> announced that Pharrell had signed a contract with the label and is releasing an album in 2014, featuring the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Happy_(Pharrell_Williams_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Happy (Pharrell Williams song) (page does not exist)">Happy</a>" from the <i>Despicable Me 2</i> soundtrack.<sup id="cite_ref-second_album_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-second_album-2">[2]</a></sup>  For this song, Pharrell has been nominated for the Academy Award for Best Original Song.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_style">Musical style</span></h2>
<p>Williams has stated that he does not have any direct influences,<sup id="cite_ref-VH1_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VH1-41">[41]</a></sup> but has expressed his admiration for several musicians, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Jackson (page does not exist)">Michael Jackson</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=J_Dilla&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="J Dilla (page does not exist)">J Dilla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevie_Wonder" title="Stevie Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donny_Hathaway" title="Donny Hathaway">Donny Hathaway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marvin_Gaye" title="Marvin Gaye">Marvin Gaye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rakim" title="Rakim">Rakim</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Q-Tip_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Q-Tip (rapper) (page does not exist)">Q-Tip</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VH1_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VH1-41">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rolling_Stone_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rolling_Stone-42">[42]</a></sup> Williams explained that <a href="/wiki/A_Tribe_Called_Quest" title="A Tribe Called Quest">A Tribe Called Quest</a>'s 1990 album, <i><a href="/wiki/People%27s_Instinctive_Travels_and_the_Paths_of_Rhythm" title="People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm">People's Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm</a></i>, caused a "turning point" in his life, which "made me see that music was art".<sup id="cite_ref-Rolling_Stone_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rolling_Stone-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Business_ventures">Business ventures</span></h2>
<p>Pharrell co-founded the clothing brands <a href="/w/index.php?title=Billionaire_Boys_Club_(clothing)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billionaire Boys Club (clothing) (page does not exist)">Billionaire Boys Club</a> and Ice Cream Footwear. He has a boutique store in New York City on West Broadway.
</p><p>In 2008, Pharrell co-designed a series of jewelry ("Blason") and glasses for <a href="/wiki/Louis_Vuitton" title="Louis Vuitton">Louis Vuitton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-touchstone_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-touchstone-43">[43]</a></sup> He has also worked on furniture with Galerie Emmanuel Perrotin and a French manufacturer, Domeau &amp; Pérès. One of his works, a molded plastic seat with human legs, was created because he "wanted to know what it was like to be in love." The chair depicts a sexual scene with a pair of female legs and male legs.
</p><p>In 2009, Pharrell unveiled a collaborative sculpture with <a href="/wiki/Takashi_Murakami" title="Takashi Murakami">Takashi Murakami</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Art_Basel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Art Basel (page does not exist)">Art Basel</a>, which spoke to the metaphor of value.<sup id="cite_ref-Interview_with_Pharrell_Williams_Art_40_Basel_2009_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Interview_with_Pharrell_Williams_Art_40_Basel_2009-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2011, it was announced that Williams would serve as Creative Director of <a href="/w/index.php?title=KarmaloopTV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="KarmaloopTV (page does not exist)">KarmaloopTV</a> alongside founder and CEO <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greg_Selkoe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greg Selkoe (page does not exist)">Greg Selkoe</a> and former <a href="/wiki/AMC_(TV_channel)" title="AMC (TV channel)">AMC</a> president Katie McEnroe.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 1, 2011, Williams launched his new <a href="/w/index.php?title=YouTube&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="YouTube (page does not exist)">YouTube</a> channel, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_am_OTHER&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I am OTHER (page does not exist)">i am OTHER</a></i> as part of YouTube's $100 million original channel initiative.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Williams will co-compose <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Amazing_Spider-Man_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Amazing Spider-Man 2 (page does not exist)">The Amazing Spider-Man 2</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Hans_Zimmer" title="Hans Zimmer">Hans Zimmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Marr" title="Johnny Marr">Johnny Marr</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Einziger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Einziger (page does not exist)">Michael Einziger</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_A._Stewart" title="David A. Stewart">David A. Stewart</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<p>Williams married his long-time girlfriend, model/designer Helen Lasichanh, on October 12, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> They have a son, Rocket Man Williams, born in November 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Despicable_Me&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Despicable Me (page does not exist)">Despicable Me</a></i> song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Despicable_Me:_Original_Motion_Picture_Soundtrack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Despicable Me: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack (page does not exist)">Rocket's Theme</a>" was written in honour of his son.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2005, Williams was voted "Best Dressed Man in the World" by <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> He is a fan of the <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Star Trek (page does not exist)">Star Trek</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> as indicated by his consistent use of the <a href="/wiki/Vulcan_salute" title="Vulcan salute">Vulcan salute</a> to signify his label name, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Star_Trak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Star Trak (page does not exist)">Star Trak</a>. He also enjoys the works of the late <a href="/wiki/Astronomer" title="Astronomer">astronomer</a> and science lecturer <a href="/wiki/Carl_Sagan" title="Carl Sagan">Carl Sagan</a>, whom he calls "a genius".<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> Williams is a skateboarder and has a <a href="/wiki/Half-pipe" title="Half-pipe">half-pipe</a> inside his home.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Williams is building a $35 million afterschool center in his hometown Virginia Beach.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> His charity <i>From One Hand To Another</i> is a foundation developed for youth between the ages of 7 and 20 in at risk communities throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>In an interview for the magazine <i>GQ Style</i> (Autumn/Winter 2013), Pharrell described his religious views: "On paper I'm a Christian, but really I'm a Universalist."
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=In_My_Mind_(Pharrell_Williams_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="In My Mind (Pharrell Williams album) (page does not exist)">In My Mind</a></i> (2006)
</li>
</ul>

|rowspan="2"|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Duo/Group_Performance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance (page does not exist)">Best Pop Duo/Group Performance</a>
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Won&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Won (page does not exist)">Template:Won</a>
|-
|rowspan="2"|"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Blurred_Lines&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blurred Lines (page does not exist)">Blurred Lines</a>" <small>(with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robin_Thicke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robin Thicke (page does not exist)">Robin Thicke</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>)</small>
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nom (page does not exist)">Template:Nom</a>
|-
|Record of the Year
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nom (page does not exist)">Template:Nom</a>
|}

|-
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_Black_Origin_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of Black Origin Awards (page does not exist)">2007</a>
|"Himself"
|Best International Male
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nominated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nominated (page does not exist)">Template:Nominated</a>
|-
|}

|Best Male

|rowspan="4"|"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Blurred_Lines_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blurred Lines (song) (page does not exist)">Blurred Lines</a>" <small>(with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robin_Thicke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robin Thicke (page does not exist)">Robin Thicke</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>)</small>
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=MTV_Video_Music_Award_for_Best_Collaboration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTV Video Music Award for Best Collaboration (page does not exist)">Best Collaboration</a>
|<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nominated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nominated (page does not exist)">Template:Nominated</a>

|-
|Best Song of the Summer
